description: A fortune-telling device from the 1950s.  The kind of moral support you didn't know you needed.
A deck of 52 playing cards.
A deck of 52 makeshift cards, made out of cardboard rectangles with simple designs drawn on them.

//: Unique mission item for the CITY_COP.
description: A photo of a smiling family on a camping trip.  One of the parents looks like a cleaner, happier version of the person you know.

//: The pom poms could make use of their own type of use_action.

player_descriptions: You make a skillful routine with the pom poms.
You move with refinement while using the pom poms.
npc_descriptions: makes a skillful routine with the pom poms.
moves with refinement while using the pom poms.

description: A pair of red and silver pom poms with plastic handles.  Using them will make you start a cheerleading routine.
A poorly taken polaroid photo of a young man wearing bell-bottoms and a fedora.  It's pretty blurry.
A wooden box containing all the equipment needed to play a game of chess.
A wooden box containing a set of round tokens used to play checkers.
A set of cards meant to play the game "Sorcery."  Each card has a fun picture of a different monster.
A game where one draws an image, and the others attempt to guess what it is.
A game where players traverse around the board buying property and swindling their friends.
A roleplaying game set in the post-apocalypse, so you can pretend to survive the apocalypse while surviving the apocalypse.
A strategy game featuring a set of tiny figurines of fantasy creatures.
A strategy game featuring a set of tiny figurines of space aliens and grotesque space marines.

name.str_pl: sets of Settlers of the Ranch

description: A strategy game where players build settlements and trade for supplies.

A wooden box containing all the pieces needed to play a game of senet, and also a extremely small guide of how to play it.  Board game from ancient Egypt, it plays as modern chess with 3x10 grid and small amount of pieces.

A very beautiful, and really huge plastic box, that contain all the pieces needed to play a game of mahjong, and also a extremely small, apparently poorly translated but comprehensible guide of how to play it.  Mahjong is a tile-based game where you need to find pairs of pieces and take the biggest score.

A polished wooden box containing all the pieces needed to play a game of chaturanga chess, and also a extremely small guide of how to play it.  Chaturanga is an ancient Indian strategy game, the ancestor of the many another chess variations - the European, Chinese, Japanese chess etc).

A very nice dark wooden box containing all the pieces needed to play a game of backgammon, and also a extremely small handwritten guide of how to play it.  Backgammon is a two-player board game played with counters and dice on table boards.  The objective of the game is to move the fifteen pieces around the board and be first to remove them from the board

A small wooden box containing all the pieces needed to play a game of latrunculi, and also a extremely small guide of how to play it. Two-player strategy board game which was played throughout the Roman Empire in the past, its require a lot of tactic and strategy.

A wooden box containing all the pieces needed to play a game of go, and also a extremely small guide of how to play it, where one side seems to be written in the Mandarin language and the other side seems to be in English.  It is two-player game, where each tries to grab more territory than the enemy.

A wooden box containing all the pieces needed to play a game of shogi, and also a extremely small guide of how to play it, with some letters in Japanese.  Also known as Japanese chess, it is a strategy board game for two players.  It was once one of the most popular board games in Japan, before the Cataclysm, and the main objective is to, though strategy, tsumi (checkmate) the opponent's osho (king).

A wooden box containing all the pieces needed to play a game of hnefatafl, and also a extremely small guide of how to play it, with some nordic rules written on it.  Also called 'Viking Chess', it was a popular game in medieval Scandinavia, there are the attackers and defenders, the attackers (located in the sides of the board), must capture the defenders king, while the defenders should get the king to one of the four corners of the board.

A wooden box containing all the pieces needed to play a game of alquerque, and also a extremely small guide of how to play it.  In the start, each player places their twelve pieces in the two rows closest to them and in the two rightmost spaces in the center row.  The game is played in turns, with one player taking white and the other black.  The goal of the game is to eliminate the opponent's pieces.
A wooden box containing all the pieces needed to play a game of dominoes.  The pieces of this one are perfectly handmade in light wood.

A cardboard tube containing exactly 60 pieces in various colors for playing a casual pick-up sticks game, alone or with friends.  The rules and values of each color are printed in the cardboard tube, being the colors light blue, dark blue, red, wine, pink, white, black, light green, dark green, cyan, gray, light brown, dark brown and yellow, each one worth a value in-game.

A fun board game, for two or more players, regarded before the Cataclysm as as a worldwide classic.  It is played on a game board with numbered, gridded squares.  A number of 'ladders' and 'snakes' are pictured on the board, each connecting two specific board squares.  The objective of the game is to navigate one's game piece, according to die rolls, from the start (bottom square) to the finish (top square), helped by climbing ladders but hindered by falling down snakes.
Ludo is a strategy board game for two to four players, in which the players race their four tokens from start to finish according to the rolls of a single dice.

It was once a popular luck-based game.  The pirate is placed into a spring-loaded barrel and rotated to randomize the unlucky slot.  Players must take it in turns to insert plastic swords into slots in the side of the barrel.  If a player inserts the sword into a specific slot (which changes randomly every time the game is played), the pirate is launched out of the barrel and the player is eliminated.  The last player remaining after all others have been eliminated wins.

A fun man-to-man board wargame.  It can be played completely alone or with friends, where when playing alone, the game scenario itself controls the opponent, via tables, charts and a 'paragraph book' which the player refer to see how the opponent is reacting.

Patrol Leader is a tactical solitaire board game.  Is this game, the player is put in the role of a patrol leader in different modern battlefield scenarios, performing missions, capturing or killing enemies, protecting its teammates and advancing in the map.  Very accurate and realistic, guaranteed fun if you like board games.

War Tanks is a tactical solitaire board game.  In this game, the player control a platoon of tanks in 6 different, fun scenarios, where in the map there are events markers.  When the player moves a tank to a point on the map that has clear line of sight to an event marker, then the player uses the mission cartridge in the cartridge reader to see if there is a paragraph number.  If there is, the player reads the relevant paragraph, which activates one or more enemy units.  Once combat is finished, the player continues to the next event marker, and each scenario outlines how the player accumulates victory points, and how many points are required to declare victory.
A game where players try to guess where the opponent placed their ships on the board.
A game where players try to figure out who murdered the butler.
This is an old nondescript North American Cylinder key.  Lord knows what lock it goes to; best not to bother with it.
A set of small blades that pinch together to cut the end off of a cigar.
A small tube meant to cut a hole in the end of a cigar.

A sturdy steel briefcase, containing what appears to be an old-fashioned drum seismograph.  The stenciled acronyms of its outer case imply it was used by XEDRA as some sort of recording device.

Thin parallel lines cover both ends of the drum, but as they approach the middle their vibrations intensify, until the ink fuses into thick red stain.
A squat tripod supports what appears to be a rather long microphone encased within a glass ampoule.  You can't tell whether it's meant to record audio, or something else entirely.
A small rod giving off a nice smell.
A short writ featuring the signed agreement of establishing a trade route.
Some type of advanced data storage device, filled with logistical data on subterranean train routes and schedules.
